title: Can you solve the rogue submarine riddle? Difficulty level: Master - Alex Rosenthal

multiple-choice.question: What was the task that the protagonist had to complete in order to prevent the nuclear missile launch?

options.label: A
options.text: Hacking into the nuclear missile launch override

options.label: B
options.text: Smuggling themselves aboard the rogue submarine

options.label: C
options.text: Finding the override code

options.label: D
options.text: Disabling the missile launch system

multiple-choice.question: Why did the boss give Minion A and Minion B different parts of the information needed to launch the nuclear missiles?

options.label: A
options.text: So that they could work together more efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: So that they couldn't share the information with each other

options.label: C
options.text: So that they could launch the missiles more quickly

options.label: D
options.text: So that they could have more control over the launch process

multiple-choice.question: What was the insight that A had when he made his first statement to B?

options.label: A
options.text: That B's number must be a prime number

options.label: B
options.text: That B's number must be a product of 1 and itself

options.label: C
options.text: That B's number must be a sum of its factors

options.label: D
options.text: That B's number must be a product of two prime numbers

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason why A's number must be 5 or 6?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the boss's numbers must be less than 7

options.label: B
options.text: Because the product of B's number must be a prime number

options.label: C
options.text: Because the sum of B's number must be a product of 1 and itself

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sum of B's number must be a sum of its factors

multiple-choice.question: What was the override code that the protagonist entered to prevent the nuclear missile launch?

options.label: A
options.text: 3 and 4

options.label: B
options.text: 5 and 6

options.label: C
options.text: 1 and 2

options.label: D
options.text: 2 and 3

title: You could have a secret twin (but not the way you think) - Kayla Mandel Sheets

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a condition where an individual has two genomes present in the tissues of their body, one belonging to them and the other to their twin?

options.label: A
options.text: Chimerism

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic mutation

options.label: C
options.text: DNA duplication

options.label: D
options.text: Mitochondrial disorder

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the term "chimerism"?

options.label: A
options.text: From Greek mythology, where a chimera is a single creature with the body of a lion, the head of a goat, and the tail of a serpent.

options.label: B
options.text: From Greek mythology, where a chimera is an amalgam of three different animals.

options.label: C
options.text: From ancient Greek, where "chimera" means "a monstrous creature composed of the parts of different animals".

options.label: D
options.text: From Latin, where "chimera" means "a creature composed of different parts".

multiple-choice.question: How can chimerism occur in an individual?

options.label: A
options.text: Only through a tissue or organ transplant

options.label: B
options.text: Only through a twin in utero

options.label: C
options.text: Through a twin in utero, a tissue or organ transplant, or between a fetus and a pregnant woman

options.label: D
options.text: Through a genetic mutation or DNA duplication

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a mother and fetus swap cells in the flow of nutrients across the placenta?

options.label: A
options.text: The mother's immune system destroys the fetal cells.

options.label: B
options.text: The fetal cells go undetected by the mother's immune system and persist in her body for years or decades.

options.label: C
options.text: The fetal cells develop into a separate individual.

options.label: D
options.text: The fetal cells are rejected by the mother's body.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to individuals with chimerism?

options.label: A
options.text: They may have visible signs of the condition, such as two-toned skin or hair.

options.label: B
options.text: They may have no visible signs of the condition.

options.label: C
options.text: They may experience genetic mutations or DNA duplication.

options.label: D
options.text: They may have a higher risk of certain diseases or disorders.

title: Earth's mysterious red glow, explained - Zoe Pierrat

multiple-choice.question: What was the unexpected wavelength of unknown origin that researchers noticed while scanning the Earth's surface with a satellite in 2009?

options.label: A
options.text: A wavelength that corresponded with densely populated areas

options.label: B
options.text: A wavelength that was a result of reflected sunlight

options.label: C
options.text: A wavelength that was emanating from places with lots of plants

options.label: D
options.text: A wavelength that was a result of human-made activities

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the process by which plants use light to grow, and in which light energy is transformed into chemical energy?

options.label: A
options.text: Respiration

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence

options.label: D
options.text: Transpiration

multiple-choice.question: What happens to excess light that plants absorb but are unable to consume, such as during the winter when leaves are frozen?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used for photosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: It is radiated back out at a different wavelength

options.label: C
options.text: It is transformed into heat and dissipated out of the leaves

options.label: D
options.text: It is absorbed by other organisms

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the phenomenon by which plants emit light at a different wavelength, producing a red glow, as observed by satellite?

options.label: A
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Respiration

options.label: D
options.text: Transpiration

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of using chlorophyll fluorescence as a measure of plant health, compared to using levels of greenness?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a more expensive method

options.label: B
options.text: It is a less reliable method

options.label: C
options.text: It can detect plant stress before visible signs appear

options.label: D
options.text: It only measures photosynthetic activity in dense forests
